column6: access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> until the election of [[Donald Trump]] in the [[2016 United States presidential election]] according to valuations of his putative assets.<ref>Rebecca Seales, [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38637123 \"Eight ways President Donald Trump will make history\"], BBC News, 2017-01-21</ref>  Washington was a commercial farmer much interested in innovations, and happily quit his public duties in 1783 and again in 1797 to manage his plantation at [[Mount Vernon]]. Washington lived an upper-class lifestyle. [[Fox hunting]] was a favorite leisure activity enjoyed by the gentry, worldwide. Like most planters in Virginia, Washington imported luxury items and other fine wares from England. He paid for them by exporting his [[Cultivation of tobacco

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Extravagant spending and the unpredictability of the tobacco market meant that many Virginia planters' financial resources were unstable. Thomas Jefferson was deeply in debt when he died, and his heirs were forced to sell [[Monticello]] to cover his debts. In 1809, [[Henry Lee III]], Robert E. Lee's father, went bankrupt and served one year in [[debtors' prison]] in [[Montross, Virginia]]; Robert was two years old at the time.<ref>{{citation
column7: title= Stratford Hall/Lee Family Tree: Henry Lee III
column8: accessdate= 20 August 2010}}</ref> Despondent and nearly broke, [[William Byrd III]] of [[Westover Plantation]] committed suicide in 1777.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Wood notes that \"Few members of the American gentry were able to live idly off the rents of tenants as the English landed aristocracy did.\"<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=The Radicalism of the American Revolution
column7: page=113}}</ref> Some landowners, especially in the Dutch areas of [[Upstate New York]], leased out their lands to tenants, but generally —\"[[Plain Folk of the Old South]]\"— ordinary farmers owned their cultivated holdings.<ref>Charles C. Bolton, \"Planters, Plain Folk, and Poor Whites in the Old South.\" in Lacy K. Ford, ed., A Companion to the Civil War and Reconstruction, (2005) pp 75-93.</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==The First Families of Virginia and the Colonial Families of Maryland==

column7: Bishop John Carroll]]]][[File:Mount Clare, Bayard & South Monroe Streets, Carroll Park (Baltimore, Independent City, Maryland).jpg
column12: Mount Clare]], one of the Carroll family residences]]

column5: Robert E. Lee's [[Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The [[First Families of Virginia]] originated with colonists from England who primarily settled at [[Jamestown, Virginia
column3: James River]] and other navigable waters in the [[Colony of Virginia]] during the 17th century. As there was a propensity to marry within their narrow social scope for many generations, many descendants bear surnames which became common in the growing colony.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Many of the original English colonists considered members of the First Families of Virginia emigrated to the [[Colony of Virginia]] during the [[English Civil War]] and [[English Interregnum]] period (1642–1660). Royalists left England on the accession to power of Oliver Cromwell and his Parliament. Because most of Virginia's leading families recognized [[Charles II of England
date=January 2020}}: Charles II]] as King following the execution of [[Charles I of England
column3: Charles I]] in 1649, Charles II is reputed to have called Virginia his \"Old Dominion\", a nickname that endures today. The affinity of many early aristocratic Virginia settlers for the Crown led to the term \"distressed Cavaliers\", often applied to the Virginia oligarchy. Many Cavaliers who served under King Charles I fled to Virginia. Thus, it came to be that the First Families of Virginia often refer to Virginia as \"Cavalier Country\". These men were offered rewards of land, etc., by King Charles II, but they had settled Virginia and so remained in Virginia.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Most of such early settlers in Virginia were so-called \"Second Sons\".  [[Primogeniture]] favored first sons' inheriting lands and titles in England. Virginia evolved in a society of second or third sons of English aristocracy who inherited [[land grant]]s or land in Virginia. They formed part of the southern elite in America.
Many of the great Virginia dynasties traced their roots to families like the [[Lee family
date=January 2020}}: Lees]] and the Fitzhughs, who traced their lineage to England's county families and baronial legacies. Some, however, came from much more humble origins; such families as the Shackelfords, who gave their name to a Virginia hamlet, rose from modest beginnings in England to a place in the Virginia firmament. Some families, like the Gilliams, arrived in Virginia in the 17th century as [[indentured servants]]; by the late 18th century they had amassed several large plantations, including [[Weston Manor]], and became landed gentry in the colony.  Families such as the [[Mathews family (Virginia)
column4: Scotch-Irish immigration]] also formed political dynasties in Old Virginia. At the same time, other once-great families were decimated not only by the [[English Civil War]], but also by the enormous power of the London merchants to whom they were in debt and who could move markets \"with the stroke of a pen.\"

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The [[Colonial families of Maryland]] were the leading families in the [[Province of Maryland]]. Several also had interests in the [[Colony of Virginia]], and the two are sometimes referred to as the [[Chesapeake Colonies]]. Many of the early settlers came from the [[West Midlands (region)
date=January 2020}}: West Midlands]] in England, although the Maryland families were composed of a variety of European nationalities, e.g. French, Irish, Welsh, Scottish, and Swedish, in addition to English.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The Carroll family is an example of a prominent political family from Maryland, of Irish descent and origin in the ancient kingdom of Éile, commonly anglicized Ely, as a branch of the ruling O'Carroll family. Another is the Mason family of Virginia, who descended from the progenitor of the Mason family, [[George Mason I]], a [[Cavalier]] member of the [[Parliament of England]] born in Worcestershire, England.  The Riggin family of Maryland who also had holdings on the [[Eastern Shore of Virginia]] is of Irish descent and origin in the [[Kingdom of Munster]]. Riggin, sometimes spelled Riggen or Regan is an anglicization of the [[Irish language
date=January 2020}}: Irish]] surname Reagh.  The Riggins are descended from [[Cormac na Haoine MacCarthy Reagh]], the 13th prince of [[Carbery (barony)
column4: Kilbrittain Castle]] near [[Kinsale]] was the principal seat of the [[MacCarthy Reagh]] family, Princes of Carbery, from the early 15th century.<ref>https://www.geni.com/people/Teague-Riggin-Sr/6000000006348527210</ref><ref>https://www.colonial-settlers-md-va.us/getperson.php?personID=I094665&tree=Tree1</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: [[Charles I of England]] granted the province [[County palatine
date=January 2020}}: palatinate]] status under [[Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore]]. The foundational charter created an aristocracy of [[lords of the manor]] for Maryland. Maryland was uniquely created as a colony for [[Catholic church
column3: Catholic]] aristocracy and [[landed gentry]], but [[Anglicanism]] eventually came to dominate, partly through influence from neighboring Virginia.

column9: title=Lyfe Jennings - Biography, Albums, Streaming Links - AllMusic
column15: R&B]] and soul singer-songwriter and record producer. He plays the guitar, [[Double bass
column16: bass]], and piano which he integrates into his music. The [[New York Times]] referred to him as a \"socially minded R&B singer\".<ref name=nyt/>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Lyfe Jennings was born on June 3, 1978 in [[Toledo, Ohio]] to a working-class family and was the middle of five kids. As stated in  \"Ghetto Superman\" and \"More Than A Girl\" from ''[[The Phoenix (Lyfe Jennings album)
date=January 2020}}: The Phoenix]]'', Lyfe lost his father at a young age. When he was a teenager, Lyfe Jennings started to perform with the group called \"The Dotsons\". \"The Dotsons\" consisted of himself, his brother, and two cousins. In the beginning of the 90s, however, the band disbanded. During this time, Lyfe  began to get into legal trouble and his musical career came to a halt when he was sent to prison at then age of 14.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In 2002, after serving 10 years in prison, Lyfe returned to his musical aspirations. Two days after his December 2002 release from prison, he recorded a four-song demo CD.After a month post release, he performed at the Apollo. He was booed as he walked onto the stage, but when the Apollo audience heard his gritty falsetto and lyrical songwriting, they were swayed to the tune of five amateur-night victories in a row. Lyfe sold about 1,000 copies of his four-song demo CD during his Apollo \"residency.\" His growing success, influenced Lyfe to move to [[New York City]] and pursue a major-label deal. [[Columbia Records]] provided him with a contract and released his debut, [[Lyfe 268-192]] in August 2004. A year after its original release, the album was reissued with a new version of \"Hypothetically\" added as bonus track featuring American Idol winner, Fantasia.
Lyfe released a more hip-hop-oriented follow-up ''[[The Phoenix (Lyfe Jennings album)
date=January 2020}}: The Phoenix]]'' arrived in August 2006, with [[Three 6 Mafia]] and [[Young Buck]] making guest appearances. ''[[Lyfe Change]]'' released in April 2008, featuring a handful of new production associates as well as a verse from rapper [[T.I.]]. Subsequently, Lyfe accepted a new deal with [[Warner Bros.]] and began working on another album, tentatively titled Sooner or Later, which he stated would be his last. The album was finally released in August 2010 and featured guest spots from [[Bryan-Michael Cox]], [[Warryn Campbell]], Fabolous, [[Bobby Valentino (American musician)
column4: Anthony Hamilton]], and [[Jazmine Sullivan]]. Lyfe completed another prison stint for his actions stemming from a 2008 domestic dispute.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: He returned to music in October 2013 with ''[[Lucid (album)
date=January 2020}}: Lucid]]'', released on the Mass Appeal label. Like all of his previous studio releases, it peaked in the Top 10 of Billboard's R&B chart. Tree of Lyfe, recorded primarily in his home studio, followed in June 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Jennings, Lyfe - Dictionary definition of Jennings, Lyfe - Encyclopedia.com: FREE online dictionary
column11: website=www.artistdirect.com}}</ref> On his new album, ''Tree of Lyfe'', Lyfe Jennings describes it as his most personal work to date and produced the majority of the album at  his home studio in Greenwood, Mississippi . When asked about his current musical mindset, Lyfe Jennings response is one of reflection and experience, \"Everybody feels like they have to reinvent themselves. I don’t think you can reinvent the truth. It is what it is. I’m not focused on reinvention. I want to go deeper. This album reaffirms the reasons why people started loving this music in the first place.\"<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=[EXCLUSIVE] S2S Visits Lyfe Jennings At Home [VIDEO] - S2SMagazine.com

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The numbers \"268-192\" attached to the end of his debut album represent the identification number he was given while incarcerated. Then Lyfe appeared on ''[[Showtime at the Apollo]]''.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news
column4: title = Ex-Convict Sings Odes to Street Life Strewn With Hope

date=January 2020}}: manager]] and ex fiancé, Associate Producer Joy Bounds<ref>{{cite web

column14: title=Elijah Jennings' 4th B-day party/fundraiser pics (Lyfe Jennings Son)

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: He has a daughter Liyah Jennings (born October 2008) with ex-girlfriend early childhood educator Anita Priestley.<ref>[https://instagram.com/p/jnZZ8DDKxJ/]{{dead link
Jennings has a son with Marquita, Lyfe Michael Jennings, born February 2011.
His youngest son, Knoah Mendoza born January 2016, with ex-girlfriend, model India Mendoza.
Jennings has two more children, both born days apart in April 2018.

According to the Marietta Daily Journal,  in October 2008  after arguing with Joy Bounds, he followed her to her family's house in [[Smyrna, Georgia]].  At the residence, he destroyed the door, fired shots in the street, and then led police on a 90 mph chase that ended when he crashed his 2005 Corvette.  In September 2010 he was sentenced to three and a half years after he pleaded guilty to multiple charges arising from the incident.<ref>{{cite web

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The link to Beyond Shelter and the Housing First development in 1988 in Los Angeles was corrected.,safe,CorrectInformation,"'''Pathways to Housing''' is a not-for-profit organization founded in 1992 by Dr. [[Sam Tsemberis]].<ref>[http://www.pathwaystohousing.org/content/our_model Pathways to Housing - Our Model] {{webarchive
column3: date=2011-10-04 }} Retrieved June 20, 2007.</ref><ref name=\"csm2002\">McCarroll, Christina., [http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/0501/p11s02-lihc.html \"Pathways to Housing the Homeless\"], [[The Christian Science Monitor]], May 1, 2002.</ref> It is the mission of Pathways to Housing to transform individual lives by ending homelessness and supporting recovery.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The organization is the originator of the [[Housing First]] model of addressing homelessness among people with severe psychiatric disabilities and substance use disorders. In Los Angeles, California in 1988, the \"Housing First\" Program at Beyond Shelter  was launched by Tanya Tull in response to a sharp increase in the number of homeless families with children.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Profile for Tanya Tull, Ashoka Fellowship
column8: archivedate=February 12, 2014}}</ref> As an innovative model, [[Housing First]] has been nationally successful at addressing homelessness largely due to its focus on consumer choice.<ref name=\"Tsemberis, S. 2004 p. 651-656\">Tsemberis, S., Gulcur, L. and Nakae, M. (2004). Housing first, consumer choice and harm reduction for homeless individuals with a dual diagnosis. American Journal of Public Health, 94, 4, p. 651-656.</ref>  Consumers choose the neighborhoods they want to live in, how their apartments are furnished, and all other decisions regarding the use of their new homes.  Consumers also determine the frequency, duration, and intensity of the support and treatment services they receive.  Consumers feel secure knowing housing will be held for them during relapse, psychiatric crisis or short incarcerations.  Most importantly though, consumers know they have a voice and often attend Tenant Advisory Council meetings, which provides a forum for input into the program and solicits ideas for changes to meet new needs.<ref>[http://www.pathwaystohousing.org/content/housing_and_services Pathways to Housing - Housing and Services] {{webarchive

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Using this consumer-driven approach, Pathways to Housing has achieved remarkable success in housing retention for its target population.  In one federally funded longitudinal random assignment study, 80% of the participants assigned to Pathways to Housing were in stable housing after 12 months compared to 24% for the three-step [https://web.archive.org/web/20071224145153/http://www.hud.gov/offices/cpd/homeless/programs/coc/ Continuum of Care] programs.<ref name=\"Tsemberis, S. 2004 p. 651-656\"/> Housing serves approximately 700 individuals living in supported scattered-site apartments throughout [[New York City]]; [[Westchester County, New York]]; [[the District of Columbia]], [[Burlington, Vermont]] and [[Philadelphia]].

In a widely cited article entitled Pathways to Housing, published in 2000, Tsemberis and Eisenberg reported on a study undertaken from 1993 to 1997 examining the effectiveness of a five-year (1993-1997)  Pathways to Housing supported housing program on 242 clients with severe psychiatric disabilities and addictions in New York City. During that time Pathways to Housing provided \"immediate access to independent scatter-site apartments for individuals with psychiatric disabilities who were homeless and living on the street.\" With an 88 percent retention rate, the \"supported housing program achieved better housing tenure than did the comparison group.\"<ref name=Tsemberis2000>{{cite journal
column6: title=Pathways to housing: supported housing for street-dwelling homeless individuals with psychiatric disabilities

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: By 2007 Pathways to Housing had an annual operating budget of $15M and was funded by grants from city, state and federal government, individual contributions, foundation grants and corporate support.<ref name=\"2007report\">{{cite report
column9: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> By 2012 Pathways to Housing had successfully housed over 3,000 people with 85-90% retention since 2002.<ref name=\"2012report\">{{cite report

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In 2010, Pathways to Housing set up a mobile video exhibit at nine locations in New York City where there were over 36,000 homeless people in 2009.<ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/dhs/html/home/home.shtml \"NYC Homeless Counts\"], ''New York City Department of Homeless Services'', 2009.</ref>  The exhibit featured an image of a homeless man sleeping on the sidewalk in downtown Manhattan projected on to a building.  Words also projected asked passersby to send a text message to help get him off the streets.  A text message sent triggered a new video loop in which the man gets up and walks in the door of his new apartment. The idea is to convey visually the organization’s approach to combatting homelessness, which emphasizes getting people who are homeless into housing first and then tackling issues like mental health and addiction.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/09/video-installation-encour_n_492377.html \"Video Installation Encourages Homeless Activism In New York City\"], ''Huffington Post'', March 9, 2010.</ref><ref>Memmott, Mark. [https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2010/03/hightech_street_show_aims_to_m.html \"High-Tech Street Show Aims To Make Us 'See' Homeless, Raise Money\"], ''National Public Radio'', March 10, 2010.</ref><ref>Wallace, Nicole. [http://philanthropy.com/blogs/prospecting/using-light-display-to-raise-awarenessmoney/21696 \"Using Light Display to Raise Awareness and Money\"], ''Chronicle of Philanthropy'', March 10, 2010.</ref>
In Calgary, Alberta, the Alex<ref>{{cite web
column8: archivedate=2014-02-22}}</ref> Pathways to Housing Calgary which opened in 2007, has 150 individuals in scatter site homes in 2013.<ref name=AnnualReport2013>{{cite report
column18: archivedate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> Client pay 30 percent of their income towards their rent: 85 percent of Pathways to Housing clients receive [[Assured Income for the Severely Handicapped]] (AISH) benefits and 15 percent receive [http://humanservices.alberta.ca/financial-support/3171.html Alberta Works]. The Alex Pathways to Housing uses a [[Housing First]] model, but it also uses Assertive Community Treatment (ACT), an integrated approach to healthcare where clients access a team of \"nurses, mental health specialists, justice specialists and substance abuse specialists.\" Director Sue Fortune is committed to the 10 Year Plan To End Homelessless in the Calgary Region. Fortune reported that the Housing First approach resulted in a 66 percent decline in days hospitalized (from one year prior to intake compared to one year in the program), a 38 percent decline in times in emergency room, a 41 percent decline in EMS events, a 79 percent decline in days in jail and a 30 percent decline in police interactions.<ref name=Fortune2013>{{cite web
column20: title=Pathways to Housing Housing First Model adapted for use in the Canadian context

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Pathways to Housing Canada describes the Housing First as a \"client-driven strategy that provides immediate access to an apartment without requiring initial participation in psychiatric treatment or treatment for sobriety.\"<ref name=Fortune2013 />

In Economic Action Plan 2013, the Federal Government of Canada proposed $119 million annually from March 2014 until March 2019—with $600 million in new funding—to renew its Homelessness Partnering Strategy (HPS). In dealing with [[homelessness in Canada]], the focus is on the Housing First model. Thus, private or public organizations across Canada are eligible to receive HPS subsidies to implement Housing First programs.<ref>Government of Canada. nd.[http://actionplan.gc.ca/en/initiative/homelessness-partnering-strategy Action Plan: Homelessness Partnering Strategy]</ref>
* O’Flaherty, Brendan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Xcp4Bna6pFEC&printsec=frontcover \"Making room : the economics of homelessness\"], Cambridge, Mass. : Harvard University Press, 1996. {{ISBN

* Quigley, John M.; Raphael, Steven, [http://urbanpolicy.berkeley.edu/pdf/QR_EJHP01PB.pdf \"The Economics of Homelessness: The Evidence from North America\"], ''European Journal of Housing Policy'' 1(3), 2001, 323–336
* [https://archive.is/20070609125726/http://cchps.columbia.edu/people/tsemberis.cfm Dr. Sam Tsemberis information] - Columbia University Center for Homelessness Prevention Studies
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20100527121025/http://hud.gov/offices/cpd/homeless/chronic.cfm Chronic Homelessness] - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.
* [http://artpathways.info/  Pathways to Housing NY, Art Workshop. The NY Resource Center offers an array of services including the popular Art Workshop, thriving since 1992]

column3: [[Mary Magdalene]] in cilice. Polychrome wood carving by [[Pedro de Mena]], Church of San Miguel and San Julian, [[Valladolid]]]]

column7: s}}, also known as a '''sackcloth''',<ref name=\"Jeffrey1992\">{{cite book
column10: title=A Dictionary of Biblical Tradition in English Literature
column16: url=https://archive.org/details/dictionaryofbibl0000unse/page/673}}</ref> was originally a [[garment]] or [[undergarment]] made of coarse cloth or animal hair (a '''hairshirt''') worn close to the skin. It is used by members of various Christian traditions (including some communicants of the Anglican,<ref name=\"KnightMason2006\">{{cite book
column21: title=Nineteenth-Century Religion and Literature: An Introduction
column28: Pusey]] regularly endured a hair shirt as well as self- imposed flagellation and fasting routines.}}</ref> Catholic,<ref name=\"StravinskasShaw1998\">{{cite book
column41: title=The Augsburg Confession: A Brief Review of Its History and an Interpretation of Its Doctrinal Articles, with Introductory Discussions on Confessional Questions
column48: title=Ecclesial Repentance: The Churches Confront Their Sinful Pasts
column54: quote=In fact, it was scandal of disunity within Methodism that led UMC leaders to address the issue of racism as the underlying cause. ... The petition for forgiveness proceeded on two distinct  but interrelated levels. Each of the approximately 3,000 persons in the assemble was called to silent personal confession of the sin of racism before God, publicly symbolized by receiving ... sackcloth ... and the imposition of ashes.}}</ref> and Scottish Presbyterian Churches<ref name=\"Yates2014\">{{cite book
column57: title=Eighteenth Century Britain: Religion and Politics 1714-1815
column63: quote=The Evangelical revival in Scotland encouraged both much stricter conditions being placed on admission to Holy Communion and the maintenance of traditional discipline within the established church. ... Lesser transgressors could be ordered by the kirk session to stand before the congregation for up to three Sundays, sometimes wearing sackcloth, and publicly acknowledge their sins before 'being subjected to a \"rant\" from the minister'.}}</ref>) as a self-imposed [[means of grace
column65: repentance]] and [[mortification of the flesh]]; it is often worn during the Christian [[penance
column66: penitential]] season of [[Lent]], especially on [[Ash Wednesday]], [[Good Friday]], and other Fridays of the Lenten season.<ref name=\"BeaulieuChartres2013\">{{cite book
column71: title=The Sanctity of Louis IX: Early Lives of Saint Louis by Geoffrey of Beaulieu and William of Chartres

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Cilices were originally made from sackcloth or coarse animal hair so they would irritate the skin. Other features were added to make cilices more uncomfortable, such as thin wires or twigs. In modern religious circles, cilices are simply any device worn for the same purposes.
The word ''cilice'' derives from the [[Latin]] ''cilicium'', a covering made of goat's hair from [[Cilicia]], a Roman [[province]] in south-east [[Asia Minor]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2012-06-30}}</ref> The reputed first Scriptural use of this exact term is in the [[Vulgate]] (Latin) translation of [[Psalms
column6: Psalm]] 35:13, ''\"Ego autem, cum mihi molesti essent, induebar cilicio.\"''  (\"But as for me, when they were sick, my clothing was sackcloth\" in the King James Bible).  The term is translated as ''hair-cloth'' in the [[Douay–Rheims Bible]], and as ''sackcloth'' in the [[King James Bible]] and [[Book of Common Prayer]].  Sackcloth can also mean [[burlap]], but is often mentioned as a symbol of [[mourning]] and was probably a form of hairshirt. {{citation needed

column5: St. Louis]] at St. Aspais Church, [[Melun]], [[France]]]]

column4: [[Ivan the Terrible]]'s cilice (16th century). The tsar wanted to die like a monk.]]

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: There is some evidence, based on analyses of both clothing represented in art and preserved skin imprint patterns at [[Çatalhöyük]] in Turkey, that the usage of the cilice predates written history. This finding has been mirrored at [[Göbekli Tepe]], another [[Anatolia
date=January 2020}}: Anatolian]] site, indicating the widespread manufacturing of cilices. Ian Hodder has argued that \"self-injuring clothing was an essential component of the Catalhöyük culturo-ritual entanglement, representing 'cleansing' and 'lightness'.\"<ref>Ian Hodder, \"Çatalhöyük: The Leopard's Tale\", Thames & Hudson, 2006.</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In Biblical times, it was the [[Jewish]] custom to wear a hairshirt (sackcloth) when mourning (Genesis 37:34, 2 Samuel 3:31, Esther 4:1), but not in order to cause harm to oneself, which is forbidden in the Jewish religion.{{cn
date=January 2020}}: date=February 2020}} In the [[New Testament]], [[John the Baptist]] wore \"a garment of camel’s hair\" (Matthew 3:4). Historically, some [[Christianity
column3: Christian]] denominations have worn sackcloth to [[mortification of the flesh
column4: mortify the flesh]] or as [[penance]] for adorning oneself.{{cn

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Cilices have been used for centuries in the [[Catholic Church]] as a mild form of bodily penance akin to [[fasting]]. [[Thomas Becket]] was wearing a hairshirt when he was [[martyr]]ed,<ref>{{Cite book
column9: pages=299, 314}}</ref> [[St. Patrick]] reputedly wore a cilice, [[Charlemagne]] was buried in a hairshirt{{cn
column10: date=February 2020}}, and [[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor
column11: Henry IV]], Holy Roman Emperor and King of Germany, famously wore one in the [[Walk to Canossa]] during the [[Investiture Controversy]]{{cn
column12: date=February 2020}}. Prince [[Henry the Navigator]] was found to be wearing a hairshirt at the time of his death in 1460.{{Citation needed
column14: St. Francis of Assisi]], [[Ignatius of Loyola
column15: St. Ignatius Loyola]] and [[Thérèse of Lisieux
column16: St. Therese of Lisieux]] are known to have used them{{cn
column17: date=February 2020}}. In modern times they have been used by [[Mother Teresa]], [[Pio of Pietrelcina
column18: St. Padre Pio]], and [[Pope Paul VI]].<ref name=\"press release\">{{cite web
column23: Discalced Carmelite]] convent of St. Teresa in Livorno, Italy, members of [[Opus Dei]] who are celibate (about 30% of the membership), and the [[Franciscan]] Brothers and Sisters of the Immaculate Conception continue an [[Asceticism
column27: pp=165, 169, 171–173}} According to [[John L. Allen Jr.
column28: John Allen]], an American Catholic writer, its practice in the Catholic Church is \"more widespread than many observers imagine\".{{sfn

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Some high church Anglicans, including [[Edward Bouverie Pusey]], wore hairshirts as a part of their spirituality.<ref name=\"KnightMason2006\"/>
In the Presbyterian [[Church of Scotland]], influenced by the [[Evangelical revival in Scotland
date=January 2020}}: evangelical revival]], penitents were dressed in sackcloth and called in front of the [[chancel]], where they were asked to admit their sins.<ref name=\"Yates2014\"/>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In some Methodist churches, on [[Ash Wednesday]], communicants, along with receiving ashes, also receive a piece of sackcloth \"as a reminder of our own sinful ways and need for repentance\".<ref>{{cite web

column5: Closeup of a metal cilice with inwardly-pointing [[Tine (structural)

date=January 2020}}: Dan Brown's]] novel ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'', one of the [[Antagonist (literature)
column4: albino]] [[Types of membership of Opus Dei
column5: numerary]] named [[List of The Da Vinci Code characters#Silas
column6: Silas]] associated with the religious organization [[Opus Dei]], wears a cilice in the form of a spiked belt around his thigh. The sensationalized depiction in the novel has been criticized for its inaccuracy in subsequent books and by Opus Dei itself, which issued a press release responding to the movie's depiction of the practice, claiming \"In reality, they cause a fairly low level of discomfort comparable to fasting. There is no blood, no injury, nothing to harm a person's health, nothing traumatic. If it caused any harm, the Church would not allow it.\"<ref name=\"press release\"/>{{sfn

column5: title= Opus Dei: An Objective Look Behind the Myths and Reality of the Most Controversial Force in the Catholic Church

This finding has been mirrored at [[Göbekli Tepe]], another [[Anatolia
date=January 2020}}: Anatolian]] site, indicating the widespread manufacturing of cilices. Ian Hodder has argued that \"self-injuring clothing was an essential component of the Catalhöyük culturo-ritual entanglement, representing 'cleansing' and 'lightness'.\"<ref>Ian Hodder, \"Çatalhöyük: The Leopard's Tale\", Thames & Hudson, 2006.</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In Biblical times, it was the [[Jewish]] custom to wear a hairshirt (sackcloth) when mourning (Genesis 37:34, 2 Samuel 3:31, Esther 4:1), but not in order to cause harm to oneself, which is forbidden in the Jewish religion.{{cn
date=January 2020}}: date=February 2020}} In the [[New Testament]], [[John the Baptist]] wore \"a garment of camel’s hair\" (Matthew 3:4). Historically, some [[Christianity
column3: Christian]] denominations have worn sackcloth to [[mortification of the flesh
column4: mortify the flesh]] or as [[penance]] for adorning oneself.{{cn

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Cilices have been used for centuries in the [[Catholic Church]] as a mild form of bodily penance akin to [[fasting]]. [[Thomas Becket]] was wearing a hairshirt when he was [[martyr]]ed{{cn
date=January 2020}}: date=February 2020}}, [[St. Patrick]] reputedly wore a cilice, [[Charlemagne]] was buried in a hairshirt{{cn
column3: date=February 2020}}, and [[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor
column4: Henry IV]], Holy Roman Emperor and King of Germany, famously wore one in the [[Walk to Canossa]] during the [[Investiture Controversy]]{{cn
column5: date=February 2020}}. Prince [[Henry the Navigator]] was found to be wearing a hairshirt at the time of his death in 1460.{{Citation needed
column7: St. Francis of Assisi]], [[Ignatius of Loyola
column8: St. Ignatius Loyola]] and [[Thérèse of Lisieux
column9: St. Therese of Lisieux]] are known to have used them{{cn
column10: date=February 2020}}. In modern times they have been used by [[Mother Teresa]], [[Pio of Pietrelcina
column11: St. Padre Pio]], and [[Pope Paul VI]].<ref name=\"press release\">{{cite web
column16: Discalced Carmelite]] convent of St. Teresa in Livorno, Italy, members of [[Opus Dei]] who are celibate (about 30% of the membership), and the [[Franciscan]] Brothers and Sisters of the Immaculate Conception continue an [[Asceticism
column20: pp=165, 169, 171–173}} According to [[John L. Allen Jr.
column21: John Allen]], an American Catholic writer, its practice in the Catholic Church is \"more widespread than many observers imagine\".{{sfn

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Some high church Anglicans, including [[Edward Bouverie Pusey]], wore hairshirts as a part of their spirituality.<ref name=\"KnightMason2006\"/>
In the Presbyterian [[Church of Scotland]], influenced by the [[Evangelical revival in Scotland
date=January 2020}}: evangelical revival]], penitents were dressed in sackcloth and called in front of the [[chancel]], where they were asked to admit their sins.<ref name=\"Yates2014\"/>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: In some Methodist churches, on [[Ash Wednesday]], communicants, along with receiving ashes, also receive a piece of sackcloth \"as a reminder of our own sinful ways and need for repentance\".<ref>{{cite web

column5: Closeup of a metal cilice with inwardly-pointing [[Tine (structural)

date=January 2020}}: Dan Brown's]] novel ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'', one of the [[Antagonist (literature)
column4: albino]] [[Types of membership of Opus Dei
column5: numerary]] named [[List of The Da Vinci Code characters#Silas
column6: Silas]] associated with the religious organization [[Opus Dei]], wears a cilice in the form of a spiked belt around his thigh. The sensationalized depiction in the novel has been criticized for its inaccuracy in subsequent books and by Opus Dei itself, which issued a press release responding to the movie's depiction of the practice, claiming \"In reality, they cause a fairly low level of discomfort comparable to fasting. There is no blood, no injury, nothing to harm a person's health, nothing traumatic. If it caused any harm, the Church would not allow it.\"<ref name=\"press release\"/>{{sfn

column5: title= Opus Dei: An Objective Look Behind the Myths and Reality of the Most Controversial Force in the Catholic Church

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/SMIGRA*/Cilicium.html On the Latin word ''cilicium''] (with photograph of a 16c hairshirt)

*[http://www.religious-vocation.com/redemptive_suffering.html Suffering and Sainthood in the Catholic Church] The importance of Penance and Mortification for those who desire to become a Catholic Saint

The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
date=January 2020}}: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>.
''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
date=January 2020}}: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand, juvenile ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' live in solitary, tend to be shy, and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age, they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring, while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics
date=January 2020}}: tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]], the [[Marquesas Islands
column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut
column4: Hsu, Kui-Ching; Chen, Jeng-Ping & Shao, Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile, benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms, unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett, M. S., Wilson, S. K., & Baird, A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology'', ''69''(5), 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing, pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however, by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish, specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish, and localized extinctions, following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al., revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growthBrooker, R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6''', 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development. Coral reef communities provide shelter, and food resources for Butterflyfish. However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: '''Richard Glenmor Beynon''', professionally known by his [[stage name]] '''BYNON''',<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web

The [[clarinet]] prodigy turned DJ/Producer/Songwriter comes from a family of musicians hailing from [[South Wales]] (U.K.). He grew up in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. He studied at [[Langley Fine Arts School]], [[Juilliard School]] ,and [[McGill University]].

date=January 2020}}: bass]], keyboards, [[piano]] and [[drums]] before becoming a clarinet player. He performed with the Surrey Youth Orchestra, the Vancouver Summer Pops Youth Orchestra and won gold at the Kiwanis International Fraser Valley Music Festival.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Collaborating with his father, BYNON arranged and produced three successful albums featuring many genres of music including classical, jazz and pop.<ref name=\":0\" />

A seasoned performer, BYNON toured around North America, with multiple dates in Europe and Asia. Highlights include Paradiso Festival at the Gorge in Seattle, a four year residency in the Las Vegas circuit featuring Legendary Pool Party REHAB and SLS, and most recently in 2018 at îleSoniq Festival, in his adopted home town of Montreal.

With his freshman releases alongside Dannic, Project 46 & Feenixpawl, his name popped up monthly on [[Beatport]] top 10 charts, (Golden Hearts, Eyes, Home) on Revealed, Ultra Records and Atlantic throughout 2014.
At the end of 2015 BYNON's massive rework Ganja Man featuring Sean Paul went viral on Youtube, accumulating over 23 Million Views.
In early 2016, BYNON decided to focus primarily on songwriting and production, working with [[Sean Paul]], [[Kaskade]], [[Ilsey Juber
column3: Mako]], Jane XØ and many more. He has been involved with major projects at Columbia, Atlantic, Sony and Warner Music. [[Corey Hart (singer)
column4: Corey Hart]] commissioned him to co-write and produce Jonathan Roy's sophomore album ''Mr. Optimist Blues,'' which included the Certified Gold Record Smash \"Daniella Denmark\".

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: He has co-written numerous #1 itunes albums and singles, and issued several solo releases and remixes in 2018.
BYNON resides in both [[Montreal]] and [[Los Angeles]].

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The ''[[18 Wheels of Steel]]'' series primarily focuses on North America. The series was published by [[ValuSoft]] from 2002, with ''Hard Truck: 18 Wheels of Steel'', to 2011, with ''18 Wheels of Steel: Extreme Trucker 2''.
The ''[[Truck Simulator]]'' series includes ''[[Euro Truck Simulator]]'', published in 2008, its sequel game, ''[[Euro Truck Simulator 2]]'', which was released in 2012.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Why The Crew Fails Where Euro Truck Simulator 2 Succeeds
column8: accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> Both games focus on truck driving in European countries, such as the [[United Kingdom]], [[Germany]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Italy]], [[France]], [[Belgium]], [[The Netherlands]], [[Austria]], [[Switzerland]].<ref name=\"vice\">{{cite web
column12: title=I Played a Truck Simulator Video Game for 30 Hours and Have Never Felt More at Peace

column34: df=dmy-all }}</ref> SCS Software has released a number of maps as [[downloadable content]] (DLC) for ''Euro Truck Simulator 2''. The first DLC, \"Going East!\", was released in late 2013 and includes a number of [[Eastern European]] countries; adding [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] and expanding on [[Poland]].<ref>{{cite web
column38: title=Euro Truck Simulator 2 heads east for its first DLC expansion
column45: title=Euro Truck Simulator 2 screenshots show upcoming Scandinavia DLC
column48: accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> A further map-expansion for the Scandinavia; including [[Denmark]], [[Norway]] and [[Sweden]]; was released on 6 May 2015.<ref name=\"pcgamer-Scand\"/><ref>{{cite web
column50: title=Euro Truck Simulator 2 – Scandinavia Gets Release Date, Teaser
column55: last=Zutter}}</ref> The update also included licensed [[Mercedes-Benz]] trademarks and branding.<ref>{{cite web
column60: trans-title=Mercedes finally officially coming to ETS 2

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Following the success of the ''Euro Truck Simulator'' series, SCS announced that the next game in the series would be ''[[American Truck Simulator]],'' released 3 February 2016. However, it released early on 2 February 2016. American Truck Simulator currently covers the western U.S. states of California, Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon, Washington, and Utah.<ref name=\"map-dlc\">{{cite web
column3: title=American Truck Simulator Map DLC Clarifications
column8: access-date=21 January 2016}}</ref> The game features officially licensed American and long nose trucks; including models by [[Peterbilt]], [[Kenworth]], and [[Volvo]] and International.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Road To Joy: American Truck Simulator Images
column17: title=American Truck Simulator images and \"moving target\" release date info
column24: title=American Truck Simulator Wiki – Everything you need to know about the game
column33: title=American Truck Simulator devs release an hour of alpha footage
column36: accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> The game originally released with [[California]] and [[Nevada]], with the state of [[Arizona]] releasing as a free DLC to owners of the game in June 2016 and [[New Mexico]] releasing as paid DLC in November 2017. Almost a year later in October 2018 the state of [[Oregon]] was also released as a paid DLC. Then, on 11 June 2019, the state of [[Washington (state)
column37: Washington]] was added as paid DLC,<ref>{{cite web
column41: access-date=2019-06-20}}</ref> with [[Utah]] releasing on 7 November 2019.<ref>{{Cite web
column51: access-date=8 November 2019}}</ref> Future states and map add-ons (like [[Idaho]]) will be sold as paid DLC.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The term '''netizen''' is a [[portmanteau]] of the words [[Internet]] and [[citizen]], as in a \"citizen of the net\" or \"net citizen.\"<ref>{{cite book
column11: title=The Expanding Commonwealth of Learning: Printing and the Net
column17: title=The Netizens and Community Networks - Presented at the Hypernetwork '95 Beppu Bay Conference
column20: date=24 November 1995}}</ref> It describes a person<ref name=\"amelia\">{{cite web
column23: title=What Does it Mean to be a Netizen?
column28: online communities]] or the Internet in general.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/netizen ''netizen''], Dictionary.com</ref><ref name=Hauben>[http://www.columbia.edu/~rh120/ch106.x01 ''The Net and Netizens by Michael Hauben''], Columbia University.</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: The term commonly also implies an interest and active engagement in improving the Internet, making it an intellectual and a social resource,<ref name=\"amelia\"/> or its surrounding political structures, especially in regard to [[open access]], [[net neutrality]] and [[Freedom of speech#The Internet and Information Society
date=January 2020}}: free speech]].<ref>[http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/0,,sid9_gci212636,00.html ''What is netizen? definition'']</ref> The term was widely adopted in the mid-1990s as a way to describe those who inhabit the new geography of the Internet.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Global Issues and Ethical Considerations in Human Enhancement Technologies
column9: accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> Internet pioneer and author [[Michael F. Hauben]] is credited with coining and popularizing the term.<ref name=\"amelia\"/><ref>{{cite web

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==Quotations from Michael and Ronda Hauben==<!--/Explanations from ...-->

date=January 2020}}: My initial research concerned the origins and development of the global discussion forum [[Usenet]]....I wanted to explore the larger Net and what it was and its significance. This is when my research uncovered the remaining details that helped me to recognize the emergence of Netizens. There are people online who actively contribute towards the development of the Net. These people understand the value of collective work and the communal aspects of public communications. These are the people who discuss and debate topics in a constructive manner, who e-mail answers to people and provide help to new-comers, who maintain FAQ files and other public information repositories, who maintain mailing lists, and so on. These are people who discuss the nature and role of this new communications medium. These are the people who as citizens of the Net I realized were netizens.
column4: source=Netizens: On the History and Impact of Usenet and the Internet<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=Netizens: On the History and Impact of Usenet and the Internet
column13: chapter=Preface: What is a Netizen}}</ref><ref name=\"heise\"/><ref name=\"regis\"/>}}

date=January 2020}}: Welcome to the 21st Century. You are a Netizen (a Net Citizen), and you exist as [[Global citizenship
column3: a citizen of the world]] thanks to the global connectivity that the Net makes possible. You consider everyone as your compatriot. You physically live in one country but you are in contact with much of the world via the global computer network. Virtually, you live next door to every other single Netizen in the world. Geographical separation is replaced by existence in the same [[cyberspace
column6: source=The Net and Netizens: The Impact the Net Has on People's Lives<ref name=\"heise\"/>}}

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Hauben describes the distinction to Internet users in general by saying:<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=The need for a Netizens Association

date=January 2020}}:
Netizens are not just anyone who comes on-line, and they are especially not people who come on-line for isolated gain or profit. They are not people who come to the Net thinking it is a service. Rather they are people who understand it takes effort and action on each and everyone's part to make the Net a regenerative and vibrant community and resource. Netizens are people who decide to devote time and effort into making the Net, this new part of our world, a better place.
[[Lurker]]s are not Netizens, and vanity home pages are not the work of Netizens. While lurking or trivial home pages do not harm the Net, they do not contribute either.}}

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==In China==<!--or \"Usage of the term/word in China?-->

In Chinese, the terms ''wǎngmín'' (网民, literally \"net-people\") and ''wǎngyǒu'' (网友, literally \"net-friend\") are commonly used terms meaning \"Internet users\", and the English word ''netizen'' is used by [[mainland China]]-based [[English language]] media to translate both terms, resulting in the frequent appearance of that English word in media reporting about China, far more frequently than the use of the word in other contexts.<ref>Brian Fung, \"[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/10/netizen-why-is-this-goofy-sounding-word-so-important-in-china/263245/ 'Netizen': Why Is This Goofy-Sounding Word So Important in China?]\", ''The Atlantic'', 11 October 2012</ref><ref>Matt Schiavenza, \"[https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/09/enough-with-the-word-netizen/279969/ Enough with the word \"Netizen\"]\", ''The Atlantic'', 25 September 2013</ref>
The international nonprofit organisation [[Reporters Without Borders]] awards an annual [[Reporters Without Borders#Netizen Prize
date=January 2020}}: Netizen Prize]] in recognition to an Internet user, [[blogger]], [[cyber-dissident]], or group who has helped to promote freedom of expression on the Internet.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=World Day Against Cyber-Censorship: new “Enemies of the Internet” list
column20: title=Reporters Without Borders award Raif Badawi the Netizen Prize for 2014
column24: date=5 November 2014}}</ref> The organisation uses the term when describing the [[political repression of cyber-dissidents]] such as [[Blog#Legal and social consequences
column25: legal consequences of blogging]] in politically repressive environments.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==See also==<!--(could also be renamed to \"related concepts\")-->

* [[Digital citizen]] – citizens (of the physical space) using the Internet as a tool in order to engage in society, politics, and government participation<ref>Mossberger, Karen. \"Digital Citizenship - The Internet, Society and Participation\" By [[Karen Mossberger]], [[Caroline Tolbert
date=January 2020}}: Caroline J. Tolbert]], and Ramona S. McNeal.\" 23 Nov. 2011. {{ISBN

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: * [[Internaut]] – operators or technically highly capable users of the Internet<ref>[http://www.isoc.org/internet/history/brief.shtml A Brief History of the Internet] from the Internet Society</ref><ref>{{cite web
* [[Cyberspace]] – the new societal territory that is inhabited by Netizens
* [[Active citizenship]] – the concept that citizens have certain roles and responsibilities to society and the environment and should actively participate
* [[List of Internet pioneers]] – those who helped erect the theoretical and technological foundation of the Internet (instead of improving its content, utility or political aspects)
* [[Participatory culture]] – a culture in which the public does not act merely as consumers and voters, but also as contributors, producers and active participants

date=January 2020}}: Welcome to the 21st Century. You are a Netizen (a Net Citizen), and you exist as [[Global citizenship
column3: a citizen of the world]] thanks to the global connectivity that the Net makes possible. You consider everyone as your compatriot. You physically live in one country but you are in contact with much of the world via the global computer network. Virtually, you live next door to every other single Netizen in the world. Geographical separation is replaced by existence in the same [[cyberspace
column6: source=The Net and Netizens: The Impact the Net Has on People's Lives<ref name=\"heise\"/>}}

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Hauben describes the distinction to Internet users in general by saying:<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=The need for a Netizens Association

date=January 2020}}:
Netizens are not just anyone who comes on-line, and they are especially not people who come on-line for isolated gain or profit. They are not people who come to the Net thinking it is a service. Rather they are people who understand it takes effort and action on each and everyone's part to make the Net a regenerative and vibrant community and resource. Netizens are people who decide to devote time and effort into making the Net, this new part of our world, a better place.
[[Lurker]]s are not Netizens, and vanity home pages are not the work of Netizens. While lurking or trivial home pages do not harm the Net, they do not contribute either.}}

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==In China==<!--or \"Usage of the term/word in China?-->

In Chinese, the terms ''wǎngmín'' (网民, literally \"net-people\") and ''wǎngyǒu'' (网友, literally \"net-friend\") are commonly used terms meaning \"Internet users\", and the English word ''netizen'' is used by [[mainland China]]-based [[English language]] media to translate both terms, resulting in the frequent appearance of that English word in media reporting about China, far more frequently than the use of the word in other contexts.<ref>Brian Fung, \"[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/10/netizen-why-is-this-goofy-sounding-word-so-important-in-china/263245/ 'Netizen': Why Is This Goofy-Sounding Word So Important in China?]\", ''The Atlantic'', 11 October 2012</ref><ref>Matt Schiavenza, \"[https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/09/enough-with-the-word-netizen/279969/ Enough with the word \"Netizen\"]\", ''The Atlantic'', 25 September 2013</ref>
The international nonprofit organisation [[Reporters Without Borders]] awards an annual [[Reporters Without Borders#Netizen Prize
date=January 2020}}: Netizen Prize]] in recognition to an Internet user, [[blogger]], [[cyber-dissident]], or group who has helped to promote freedom of expression on the Internet.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=World Day Against Cyber-Censorship: new “Enemies of the Internet” list
column20: title=Reporters Without Borders award Raif Badawi the Netizen Prize for 2014
column24: date=5 November 2014}}</ref> The organisation uses the term when describing the [[political repression of cyber-dissidents]] such as [[Blog#Legal and social consequences
column25: legal consequences of blogging]] in politically repressive environments.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: ==See also==<!--(could also be renamed to \"related concepts\")-->

* [[Digital citizen]] – citizens (of the physical space) using the Internet as a tool in order to engage in society, politics, and government participation<ref>Mossberger, Karen. \"Digital Citizenship - The Internet, Society and Participation\" By [[Karen Mossberger]], [[Caroline J. Tolbert]], and Ramona S. McNeal.\" 23 Nov. 2011. {{ISBN

* [[Internaut]] – operators or technically highly capable users of the Internet<ref>[http://www.isoc.org/internet/history/brief.shtml A Brief History of the Internet] from the Internet Society</ref><ref>{{cite web
* [[Cyberspace]] – the new societal territory that is inhabited by Netizens
* [[Active citizenship]] – the concept that citizens have certain roles and responsibilities to society and the environment and should actively participate
* [[List of Internet pioneers]] – those who helped erect the theoretical and technological foundation of the Internet (instead of improving its content, utility or political aspects)
* [[Participatory culture]] – a culture in which the public does not act merely as consumers and voters, but also as contributors, producers and active participants

column3: title=Sammy Guevara Graces Us With His Presence
column9: accessdate=December 6, 2019}}</ref> (born July 28, 1993) is a [[Cuban-American]]<ref name=\"TIJ\"/> [[Professional wrestling
column10: professional wrestler]]. He is signed to [[All Elite Wrestling]] (AEW), [[DDT Pro Wrestling]], and [[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide]] (AAA), where he is a former [[AAA World Cruiserweight Champion]]. He has also appeared for promotions such as [[Major League Wrestling]] (MLW), [[Evolve Wrestling]], [[Lucha Underground]], and [[Pro Wrestling Guerrilla]] (PWG).

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: He is the current Adrenaline Pro Wrestling Gladiator Champion.
Guevara made his first appearance for a major [[professional wrestling promotion]] on January 5, 2013 for the [[National Wrestling Alliance]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=NWA Wrestling Revolution: NWA Invasion « Events Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database
column4: website=www.cagematch.net}}</ref> He made his [[Pro Wrestling Guerrilla]] (PWG) debut at the [[Battle of Los Angeles (professional wrestling)#2017
column5: 2017 Battle of Los Angeles tournament]] where he got eliminated in the quarterfinals.<ref name=\"f4wonline\">{{cite web
column8: title=PWG BOLA night two results: First round concludes
column12: title=PWG ASW night two results: Triple threat World title match
column13: accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref> On April 7, 2015, Guevara wrestled a tag team dark match teaming with [[Tony Guevara]] in a losing effort against [[Los Matadores]]. At PWG's Bask In His Glory event in May 2018, Guevara faced the [[PWG World Championship
column15: WALTER]] in the main event for the title, but was defeated.<ref name=\"f4wonline3\">{{cite web
column18: title=PWG Bask In His Glory results: Keith Lee's farewell
column19: accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref> Guevara appeared in the [[Lucha Underground (season 4)
column24: title=Resultados Lucha Underground 17 de octubre de 2018
column29: title=Resultados Lucha Undergroud Ultima Lucha Cuatro (Parte 1)
column31: accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref> He won the [[PWFP Ultimate Championship]] of [[Pro Wrestling Federation of Pakistan]] in [[PWFP Rumble in Pakistan
column32: Rumble in Pakistan]] on April 28, 2019.<ref name=\"Dreamworld\">{{cite web
column37: accessdate=May 13, 2019}}</ref> However, he lost to championship due to not defending it for more than 340 days. On December 7, 2017, Guevara made his debut for [[Major League Wrestling]] (MLW).<ref>{{cite web
column39: title=MLW Never Say Never « Events Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database
column40: website=www.cagematch.net}}</ref> He made multiple appearances for MLW's television program, ''[[MLW Fusion]]'' in 2018.<ref>https://prowrestling.net/site/2019/01/29/mlw-parts-ways-with-sammy-guevara/

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Guevara made his [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide]] debut at [[Verano de Escándalo (2018)
column7: accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref> He won the [[AAA World Cruiserweight Championship]] at the [[Triplemanía XXVI]] annual event on August<ref name=\"solowrestling4\">{{cite web
column10: title=Sammy Guevara se convierte en el nuevo Campeón de Peso Crucero de AAA
column12: accessdate=January 18, 2019}}</ref> before losing it to [[Laredo Kid]] on February 16, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=AAA TV-Taping « Events Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database
column16: access-date=2019-12-04}}</ref> At [[Triplemanía XXVII]], Guevara teamed up with [[Scarlett Bordeaux]] in a match for the [[AAA World Mixed Tag Team Championship]] where they were unsuccessful.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=AAA Triplemania XXVII « Events Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: On February 7, 2019, Guevara was announced as a roster member of [[All Elite Wrestling]] (AEW).<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Watch Live - AEW Double Or Nothing Ticket Announcement Party - Fightful Wrestling
column4: website=www.fightful.com}}</ref> On October 2, 2019, he was defeated by [[Cody Rhodes]] in the opening match of the inaugural episode of ''[[AEW Dynamite]]'',<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=AEW On TNT October 2nd, 2019 {{!}} AEW {{!}} Official Website
column9: access-date=2019-10-17}}</ref> Later on the same show, Guevara would form a [[Heel (professional wrestling)
column10: villainous]] alliance with [[Chris Jericho]], [[Jake Hager]], [[Santana and Ortiz]]. The group was named \"[[The Inner Circle (professional wrestling)
column11: The Inner Circle]]\" while Guevara acquired the nickname \"Spanish God\". He lost his first major [[pay-per-view]] match against [[Darby Allin]] at the [[AEW Revolution

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: '''Nicholas''' \"'''Nick'''\" '''Baines''' (born 13 November 1957) is a British [[Anglican]] bishop. He has been the [[Anglican Bishop of Leeds
date=January 2020}}: Bishop of Leeds]] since 8 June 2014.<ref name=\"leeds10\">[http://www.gov.uk/government/news/diocese-of-leeds-the-right-reverend-nicholas-baines-approved Number 10 – Diocese of Leeds: the Right Reverend Nicholas Baines approved] (Accessed 4 February 2014)</ref> He is a former [[Bishop of Bradford (diocese)
column3: Bishop of Bradford]], the [[diocesan bishop]] of the [[Anglican]] [[Diocese of Bradford]] (from 1 April 2011 until 20 April 2014).

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Baines was educated at Holt Comprehensive School, [[South Liverpool]], before gaining a [[Bachelor of Arts]] honours degree (BAHons) in German and French at the [[University of Bradford]]. He worked as a linguist at [[GCHQ]] for four years<ref>\"Hungry for Hope\". See extract at [http://www.churchofscotland.org.uk/shop/catalog/product_info.php?cPath=34&products_id=177 Church of Scotland bookshop] {{webarchive
column3: date=2009-01-05 }}</ref> prior to training for ordination at [[Trinity College, Bristol]], where he gained a [[Bachelor of Arts]] [[honours degree]] {BA(Hons)} in theological studies.<ref name=\"prc\">{{cite web

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Baines was made a deacon at [[Petertide]] 1987 (5 July) by [[George Hacker (bishop)
column8: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> and ordained a priest the Petertide following (3 July 1988) by [[David Halsey]], [[Bishop of Carlisle]], both times at [[Carlisle Cathedral]].<ref>{{Church Times
column14: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> His first appointments were as assistant curate at [[St Thomas' Church, Kendal]] and St Catherine's [[Crook, Cumbria
column19: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> He then moved to [[Leicester]], becoming briefly associate minister of [[Holy Trinity Church, Leicester
column20: Holy Trinity, Leicester]], and then [[Vicar]] of [[Rothley, Leicestershire
column21: Rothley]] (1992-2000), during which time he was also chaplain to an adult mental health unit, before becoming Rural Dean of Goscote in 1995.<ref name=\"prc\" /> In 2000, Baines became the [[Archdeacon of Lambeth]] in the Diocese of Southwark.<ref>{{Who's Who
column27: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> He also oversaw the diocese's children and youth policies and was a member of the [[General Synod of the Church of England]] from 1995 until 2005.

date=January 2020}}: area]] Bishop of Croydon in 2003, succeeding [[Wilfred Wood (bishop)
column3: Wilfred Wood]]. He was [[consecrated]] by [[Rowan Williams]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] and installed in [[Southwark Cathedral]] on 8 May 2003.<ref name=\"prc\" />

date=January 2020}}: confirmation]] of Baines' election to the see of Bradford was on 1 April 2011<ref>[http://www.archbishopofyork.org/articles.php/976/new-bishop-for-bradford-diocese Archbishop of York – New Bishop for Bradford Diocese] (Accessed 11 April 2014)</ref> and he was enthroned at [[Bradford Cathedral]] on 21 May 2011.<ref name=\"bd1\">{{cite web
column7: archivedate=8 November 2011}}</ref> On 29 May 2013, he consecrated [[Nick Dill]] as [[Bishop of Bermuda]] on behalf of [[Justin Welby]], Archbishop of Canterbury.<ref>[http://www.anglican.ink/article/extra-provincial-dioceses-under-jurisdiction-archbishop-canterbury Anglican Ink — Extra-Provincial Dioceses under the jurisdiction of the Archbishop of Canterbury] (Accessed 31 January 2016)</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: On 4 February 2014, it was announced that Baines would become the diocesan and area [[Anglican Bishop of Leeds
date=January 2020}}: Bishop of Leeds]]<ref name=\"leeds10\" /> upon the [[Confirmation of bishops
column3: confirmation of his election]] on 8 June;<ref name=\"baines-wyad\">{{cite web
column4: title=Bishop of Bradford Announced as First Bishop of Leeds for the new Diocese
column6: website=The Transformation Programme for The Diocese of West Yorkshire and the Dales
column11: url-status=dead}}</ref> he was acting diocesan and area bishop from 22 April 2014<ref name=\"leeds85\">{{cite web
column12: title=First new diocese for more than 85 years created on April 20
column14: website=The Transformation Programme for The Diocese of West Yorkshire and the Dales
column19: url-status=dead}}</ref> (he was licensed as an [[honorary assistant bishop]] of the [[Diocese of York]] to facilitate the acting role.)<ref name=\"rebirth\">{{Church Times
column20: title = Yorkshire dioceses will celebrate Paschal rebirth

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: On 2014 he took his seat in the House of Lords as one of the Lords Spiritual.

Baines is an experienced broadcaster, regularly appearing on ''Pause for Thought'' on [[BBC Radio 2]]. While in Leicester he used to broadcast regularly on [[BBC Radio Leicester]] and [[Leicester Sound]] and twice received a commendation in the Andrew Cross Awards for religious broadcasting.
Baines married his wife, Linda, in 1980, and they have three children.

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: '''Nicholas''' \"'''Nick'''\" '''Baines''' (born 13 November 1957) is a British [[Anglican]] bishop. He has been the [[Anglican Bishop of Leeds
date=January 2020}}: Bishop of Leeds]] since 8 June 2014.<ref name=\"leeds10\">[http://www.gov.uk/government/news/diocese-of-leeds-the-right-reverend-nicholas-baines-approved Number 10 – Diocese of Leeds: the Right Reverend Nicholas Baines approved] (Accessed 4 February 2014)</ref> He is a former [[Bishop of Bradford (diocese)
column3: Bishop of Bradford]], the [[diocesan bishop]] of the [[Anglican]] [[Diocese of Bradford]] (from 1 April 2011 until 20 April 2014).

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Baines was educated at Holt Comprehensive School, [[South Liverpool]], before gaining a [[Bachelor of Arts]] honours degree (BAHons) in German and French at the [[University of Bradford]]. He worked as a linguist at [[GCHQ]] for four years<ref>\"Hungry for Hope\". See extract at [http://www.churchofscotland.org.uk/shop/catalog/product_info.php?cPath=34&products_id=177 Church of Scotland bookshop] {{webarchive
column3: date=2009-01-05 }}</ref> prior to training for ordination at [[Trinity College, Bristol]], where he gained a [[Bachelor of Arts]] [[honours degree]] {BA(Hons)} in theological studies.<ref name=\"prc\">{{cite web

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Baines was made a deacon at [[Petertide]] 1987 (5 July) by [[George Hacker (bishop)
column8: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> and ordained a priest the Petertide following (3 July 1988) by [[David Halsey]], [[Bishop of Carlisle]], both times at [[Carlisle Cathedral]].<ref>{{Church Times
column14: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> His first appointments were as assistant curate at [[St Thomas' Church, Kendal]] and St Catherine's [[Crook, Cumbria
column19: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> He then moved to [[Leicester]], becoming briefly associate minister of [[Holy Trinity Church, Leicester
column20: Holy Trinity, Leicester]], and then [[Vicar]] of [[Rothley, Leicestershire
column21: Rothley]] (1992-2000), during which time he was also chaplain to an adult mental health unit, before becoming Rural Dean of Goscote in 1995.<ref name=\"prc\" /> In 2000, Baines became the [[Archdeacon of Lambeth]] in the Diocese of Southwark.<ref>{{Who's Who
column27: accessed = 10 June 2017 }}</ref> He also oversaw the diocese's children and youth policies and was a member of the [[General Synod of the Church of England]] from 1995 until 2005.

date=January 2020}}: area]] Bishop of Croydon in 2003, succeeding [[Wilfred Wood (bishop)
column3: Wilfred Wood]]. He was [[consecrated]] by [[Rowan Williams]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] and installed in [[Southwark Cathedral]] on 8 May 2003.<ref name=\"prc\" />

date=January 2020}}: confirmation]] of Baines' election to the see of Bradford was on 1 April 2011<ref>[http://www.archbishopofyork.org/articles.php/976/new-bishop-for-bradford-diocese Archbishop of York – New Bishop for Bradford Diocese] (Accessed 11 April 2014)</ref> and he was enthroned at [[Bradford Cathedral]] on 21 May 2011.<ref name=\"bd1\">{{cite web
column7: archivedate=8 November 2011}}</ref> On 29 May 2013, he consecrated [[Nick Dill]] as [[Bishop of Bermuda]] on behalf of [[Justin Welby]], Archbishop of Canterbury.<ref>[http://www.anglican.ink/article/extra-provincial-dioceses-under-jurisdiction-archbishop-canterbury Anglican Ink — Extra-Provincial Dioceses under the jurisdiction of the Archbishop of Canterbury] (Accessed 31 January 2016)</ref>

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: On 4 February 2014, it was announced that Baines would become the diocesan and area [[Anglican Bishop of Leeds
date=January 2020}}: Bishop of Leeds]]<ref name=\"leeds10\" /> upon the [[Confirmation of bishops
column3: confirmation of his election]] on 8 June;<ref name=\"baines-wyad\">{{cite web
column4: title=Bishop of Bradford Announced as First Bishop of Leeds for the new Diocese
column6: website=The Transformation Programme for The Diocese of West Yorkshire and the Dales
column11: url-status=dead}}</ref> he was acting diocesan and area bishop from 22 April 2014<ref name=\"leeds85\">{{cite web
column12: title=First new diocese for more than 85 years created on April 20
column14: website=The Transformation Programme for The Diocese of West Yorkshire and the Dales
column19: url-status=dead}}</ref> (he was licensed as an [[honorary assistant bishop]] of the [[Diocese of York]] to facilitate the acting role.)<ref name=\"rebirth\">{{Church Times
column20: title = Yorkshire dioceses will celebrate Paschal rebirth

,safe,Rian CG,"{{Use mdy dates: Baines is an experienced broadcaster, regularly appearing on ''Pause for Thought'' on [[BBC Radio 2]]. While in Leicester he used to broadcast regularly on [[BBC Radio Leicester]] and [[Leicester Sound]] and twice received a commendation in the Andrew Cross Awards for religious broadcasting.
Baines married his wife, Linda, in 1980, and they have three children.
